title: How to Make M&M Cupcakes

steps.headline: Preheat your oven to 350°F (180°C/Gas Mark 4).
steps.description: Place paper cases into your cupcake tray, or spray the cupcake tray with non-stick greasing spray. You can use your own recipe. Prepare it as you usually would, then click here.

steps.headline: Combine the dry ingredients in a large mixing bowl.
steps.description: Sift the flour into a large mixing bowl. Add the cocoa powder, baking powder, and espresso powder. Mix the flour well with a whisk until the cocoa and espresso powders are distributed evenly throughout. Set the bowl aside.

steps.headline: Cream the butter and sugar in a separate bowl.
steps.description: Keep mixing them together until the mixture is light and fluffy. You can do this by hand in a bowl with a handheld beater. You can also use an electric stand mixer or a food processor.

steps.headline: Beat the eggs one at a time, then add the milk and vanilla.
steps.description: Add the eggs in one at a time, beating the batter well after each one. Next, stir in the milk and the vanilla extract. Keep mixing until the color and texture are consistent. There should be no streaks or swirls of unmixed vanilla or egg yolk. If the egg mixture curdles, stir in 1 tablespoon of your flour mixture.

steps.headline: Gradually add the flour mixture into the butter mixture.
steps.description: Pour half of the flour mixture into the butter mixture. Stir it in well, then add the remaining half. Keep mixing using a medium speed setting until the two are just mixed together. Be careful not to over-stir.

steps.headline: Fold one bag of M&M's into the batter.
steps.description: Tear open a 5-ounce (141-gram) bag of M&M's. Stir them into the batter with a rubber spatula. Be sure to scrape the bottom of the bowl so that the M&Ms mix in evenly. You can use plain M&M's, but the "Crispy" kind would be much better.

steps.headline: Transfer the batter into the prepared muffin tin.
steps.description: Fill each well no more than ⅔ to ¾ of the way, otherwise the batter will overflow as it bakes. Use an ice cream scoop or a soup ladle to fill the cups. This way, you can be sure that each cup gets the same amount. You will need about 3 tablespoons (45 milliliters) of batter per cupcake.

steps.headline: Bake the cupcakes, then allow them cool.
steps.description: Bake the cupcakes for 18 to 30 minutes. They are ready when a toothpick poked into the center comes out clean. Let them cool in the tin for 5 minutes, then pull them out and let them finish cooling on a wire rack. The cupcakes must be completely cooled before you frost them. If they are warm, the frosting will melt.

steps.headline: Prepare the frosting.
steps.description: Mix together the butter and half of the icing sugar. Add in the rest of the sugar and the cocoa powder. Mix well until the color and texture are consistent. You can do this with a handheld beater, an electric mixer, or a food processor fitted with whisks. You can also use your own frosting recipe if you prefer. If the frosting is too smooth, add more icing sugar. If the frosting is too stiff, add in 2 to 4 tablespoons (30 to 60 milliliters) of milk.

steps.headline: Pipe the frosting onto the completely-cooled cupcakes.
steps.description: Fit a piping bag with a large, open star tip. Fill it with frosting, then pipe the frosting onto each cupcake. For a twist, pipe the frosting around the outer edge of each cupcake two times to create a well.

steps.headline: Sprinkle the M&M's on top of each cupcake.
steps.description: You can use the M&M's whole, or you can crush them into smaller pieces using a blender or food processor. You may not end up using the entire bag of M&M's. For a twist, fill the frosting wells with M&M's.

steps.headline: Preheat your oven to 350°F (180°C/Gas Mark 4).
steps.description: Line a standard-sized, 12-hole muffin tin with paper liners. You can do this method using your own cupcake recipe. If you are using your own recipe, prepare it as you normally would, then [#cut|click here]] to continue.

steps.headline: Mix together the dry ingredients, except for the sugar.
steps.description: Pour the flour, cocoa powder, baking soda, and baking powder into a large mixing bowl. Mix everything together, then set the bowl aside.

steps.headline: Cream the butter and the sugars together.
steps.description: You can do this in a large bowl with a handheld beater, in a stand mixer, or in a food processor. Beat the three together until they turn light and fluffy.

steps.headline: Mix in the eggs gradually, then add the milk and vanilla extract.
steps.description: Add the eggs into the butter mixture one by one. Beat the mixture well after each egg that you add. At the very end, stir in the buttermilk and the vanilla extract.

steps.headline: Slowly add the flour mixture into the butter mixture.
steps.description: Pour half of the flour mixture into the butter mixture. Stir it in, then add the remaining half. Mix everything together using a medium speed setting until just combined.

steps.headline: Pour the batter into the prepared muffin tin.
steps.description: Fill each well no more than ⅔ to ¾ of the way, otherwise the batter may overflow. To make things easier, use a soup ladle or an ice cream scoop to fill the wells. Plan on using about 3 tablespoons (45 milliliters) of batter per cupcake.

steps.headline: Bake the cupcakes for 18 to 20 minutes, then let them cool.
steps.description: The cupcakes are ready when a toothpick inserted into the middle comes out clean. Let the cupcakes cool in the tin for 5 minutes, then transfer them to a wire rack to finish cooling off.

steps.headline: Cut a well into the middle of each cupcake.
steps.description: If you have not already, let the cupcakes cool off completely first. Next, cut a 1-inch (2.54-centimeter) wide, 1-inch (2.54-centimeter) deep hole into each cupcake. You can do this with a paring knife or with a small spoon. Discard the pats that you cut out, or save them for making cake pops. Paring knife: set the knife into the top of the cupcake at a 45-degree angle. Cut a cone-shape out of the middle of the cupcake. Spoon: use a melon scoop or a spoon to scoop out the middle of the cupcake.

steps.headline: Fill the wells with mini M&M's.
steps.description: If you are making these for a gender-reveal party, consider using pink (for a girl) or blue (for a boy). Set the cupcakes aside when you are done. Make sure that the inside of the cupcakes are cool before you fill them with M&M's. If they are warm, the candy will melt.

steps.headline: Prepare the icing.
steps.description: Cream the butter using a handheld beater, electric mixer, or food processor fitted with whisks. Beat in 1 cup (125 grams) of the icing sugar,  then add 1 to 2 tablespoons (15 to 30 milliliters) of milk. Add in the rest of the powdered sugar, 1 cup (125 grams) at a time. If the frosting is too stiff, add in 1 to 2 more tablespoons (15 to 30 milliliters) of milk. You can also use your own icing recipe instead. If this is for a gender reveal party, consider coloring the frosting purple to leave people guessing.

steps.headline: Pipe the frosting onto the cupcakes.
steps.description: Fit a piping bag with a large, open star tip. Pipe the frosting onto the cupcakes, making sure to cover up the M&M's. If you have any M&M's left over, you can stick them on top of the frosting. You can also grind them up in a blender or food processor, then sprinkle them over the frosting instead.

steps.headline: Finished!

text: Making Basic Cupcakes Preheat your oven to 350°F (180°C/Gas Mark 4). Place paper cases into your cupcake tray, or spray the cupcake tray with non-stick greasing spray. You can use your own recipe. Prepare it as you usually would, then click here. Combine the dry ingredients in a large mixing bowl. Sift the flour into a large mixing bowl. Add the cocoa powder, baking powder, and espresso powder. Mix the flour well with a whisk until the cocoa and espresso powders are distributed evenly throughout. Set the bowl aside. Cream the butter and sugar in a separate bowl. Keep mixing them together until the mixture is light and fluffy. You can do this by hand in a bowl with a handheld beater. You can also use an electric stand mixer or a food processor. Beat the eggs one at a time, then add the milk and vanilla. Add the eggs in one at a time, beating the batter well after each one. Next, stir in the milk and the vanilla extract. Keep mixing until the color and texture are consistent. There should be no streaks or swirls of unmixed vanilla or egg yolk. If the egg mixture curdles, stir in 1 tablespoon of your flour mixture. Gradually add the flour mixture into the butter mixture. Pour half of the flour mixture into the butter mixture. Stir it in well, then add the remaining half. Keep mixing using a medium speed setting until the two are just mixed together. Be careful not to over-stir. Fold one bag of M&M's into the batter. Tear open a 5-ounce (141-gram) bag of M&M's. Stir them into the batter with a rubber spatula. Be sure to scrape the bottom of the bowl so that the M&Ms mix in evenly. You can use plain M&M's, but the "Crispy" kind would be much better. Transfer the batter into the prepared muffin tin. Fill each well no more than ⅔ to ¾ of the way, otherwise the batter will overflow as it bakes. Use an ice cream scoop or a soup ladle to fill the cups. This way, you can be sure that each cup gets the same amount. You will need about 3 tablespoons (45 milliliters) of batter per cupcake. Bake the cupcakes, then allow them cool. Bake the cupcakes for 18 to 30 minutes. They are ready when a toothpick poked into the center comes out clean. Let them cool in the tin for 5 minutes, then pull them out and let them finish cooling on a wire rack. The cupcakes must be completely cooled before you frost them. If they are warm, the frosting will melt. Prepare the frosting. Mix together the butter and half of the icing sugar. Add in the rest of the sugar and the cocoa powder. Mix well until the color and texture are consistent. You can do this with a handheld beater, an electric mixer, or a food processor fitted with whisks. You can also use your own frosting recipe if you prefer. If the frosting is too smooth, add more icing sugar. If the frosting is too stiff, add in 2 to 4 tablespoons (30 to 60 milliliters) of milk. Pipe the frosting onto the completely-cooled cupcakes. Fit a piping bag with a large, open star tip. Fill it with frosting, then pipe the frosting onto each cupcake. For a twist, pipe the frosting around the outer edge of each cupcake two times to create a well. Sprinkle the M&M's on top of each cupcake. You can use the M&M's whole, or you can crush them into smaller pieces using a blender or food processor. You may not end up using the entire bag of M&M's. For a twist, fill the frosting wells with M&M's. Making Filled Cupcakes Preheat your oven to 350°F (180°C/Gas Mark 4). Line a standard-sized, 12-hole muffin tin with paper liners. You can do this method using your own cupcake recipe. If you are using your own recipe, prepare it as you normally would, then [#cut|click here]] to continue. Mix together the dry ingredients, except for the sugar. Pour the flour, cocoa powder, baking soda, and baking powder into a large mixing bowl. Mix everything together, then set the bowl aside. Cream the butter and the sugars together. You can do this in a large bowl with a handheld beater, in a stand mixer, or in a food processor. Beat the three together until they turn light and fluffy. Mix in the eggs gradually, then add the milk and vanilla extract. Add the eggs into the butter mixture one by one. Beat the mixture well after each egg that you add. At the very end, stir in the buttermilk and the vanilla extract. Slowly add the flour mixture into the butter mixture. Pour half of the flour mixture into the butter mixture. Stir it in, then add the remaining half. Mix everything together using a medium speed setting until just combined. Pour the batter into the prepared muffin tin. Fill each well no more than ⅔ to ¾ of the way, otherwise the batter may overflow. To make things easier, use a soup ladle or an ice cream scoop to fill the wells. Plan on using about 3 tablespoons (45 milliliters) of batter per cupcake. Bake the cupcakes for 18 to 20 minutes, then let them cool. The cupcakes are ready when a toothpick inserted into the middle comes out clean. Let the cupcakes cool in the tin for 5 minutes, then transfer them to a wire rack to finish cooling off. Cut a well into the middle of each cupcake. If you have not already, let the cupcakes cool off completely first. Next, cut a 1-inch (2.54-centimeter) wide, 1-inch (2.54-centimeter) deep hole into each cupcake. You can do this with a paring knife or with a small spoon. Discard the pats that you cut out, or save them for making cake pops. Paring knife: set the knife into the top of the cupcake at a 45-degree angle. Cut a cone-shape out of the middle of the cupcake. Spoon: use a melon scoop or a spoon to scoop out the middle of the cupcake. Fill the wells with mini M&M's. If you are making these for a gender-reveal party, consider using pink (for a girl) or blue (for a boy). Set the cupcakes aside when you are done. Make sure that the inside of the cupcakes are cool before you fill them with M&M's. If they are warm, the candy will melt. Prepare the icing. Cream the butter using a handheld beater, electric mixer, or food processor fitted with whisks. Beat in 1 cup (125 grams) of the icing sugar,  then add 1 to 2 tablespoons (15 to 30 milliliters) of milk. Add in the rest of the powdered sugar, 1 cup (125 grams) at a time. If the frosting is too stiff, add in 1 to 2 more tablespoons (15 to 30 milliliters) of milk. You can also use your own icing recipe instead. If this is for a gender reveal party, consider coloring the frosting purple to leave people guessing. Pipe the frosting onto the cupcakes. Fit a piping bag with a large, open star tip. Pipe the frosting onto the cupcakes, making sure to cover up the M&M's. If you have any M&M's left over, you can stick them on top of the frosting. You can also grind them up in a blender or food processor, then sprinkle them over the frosting instead. Finished!
sentences: Making Basic Cupcakes Preheat your oven to 350°F (180°C/Gas Mark 4).
Place paper cases into your cupcake tray, or spray the cupcake tray with non-stick greasing spray.
You can use your own recipe.
Prepare it as you usually would, then click here.
Combine the dry ingredients in a large mixing bowl.
Sift the flour into a large mixing bowl.
Add the cocoa powder, baking powder, and espresso powder.
Mix the flour well with a whisk until the cocoa and espresso powders are distributed evenly throughout.
Set the bowl aside.
Cream the butter and sugar in a separate bowl.
Keep mixing them together until the mixture is light and fluffy.
You can do this by hand in a bowl with a handheld beater.
You can also use an electric stand mixer or a food processor.
Beat the eggs one at a time, then add the milk and vanilla.
Add the eggs in one at a time, beating the batter well after each one.
Next, stir in the milk and the vanilla extract.
Keep mixing until the color and texture are consistent.
There should be no streaks or swirls of unmixed vanilla or egg yolk.
If the egg mixture curdles, stir in 1 tablespoon of your flour mixture.
Gradually add the flour mixture into the butter mixture.
Pour half of the flour mixture into the butter mixture.
Stir it in well, then add the remaining half.
Keep mixing using a medium speed setting until the two are just mixed together.
Be careful not to over-stir.
Fold one bag of M&M's into the batter.
Tear open a 5-ounce (141-gram) bag of M&M's.
Stir them into the batter with a rubber spatula.
Be sure to scrape the bottom of the bowl so that the M&Ms mix in evenly.
You can use plain M&M's, but the "Crispy" kind would be much better.
Transfer the batter into the prepared muffin tin.
Fill each well no more than ⅔ to ¾ of the way, otherwise the batter will overflow as it bakes.
Use an ice cream scoop or a soup ladle to fill the cups.
This way, you can be sure that each cup gets the same amount.
You will need about 3 tablespoons (45 milliliters) of batter per cupcake.
Bake the cupcakes, then allow them cool.
Bake the cupcakes for 18 to 30 minutes.
They are ready when a toothpick poked into the center comes out clean.
Let them cool in the tin for 5 minutes, then pull them out and let them finish cooling on a wire rack.
The cupcakes must be completely cooled before you frost them.
If they are warm, the frosting will melt.
Prepare the frosting.
Mix together the butter and half of the icing sugar.
Add in the rest of the sugar and the cocoa powder.
Mix well until the color and texture are consistent.
You can do this with a handheld beater, an electric mixer, or a food processor fitted with whisks.
You can also use your own frosting recipe if you prefer.
If the frosting is too smooth, add more icing sugar.
If the frosting is too stiff, add in 2 to 4 tablespoons (30 to 60 milliliters) of milk.
Pipe the frosting onto the completely-cooled cupcakes.
Fit a piping bag with a large, open star tip.
Fill it with frosting, then pipe the frosting onto each cupcake.
For a twist, pipe the frosting around the outer edge of each cupcake two times to create a well.
Sprinkle the M&M's on top of each cupcake.
You can use the M&M's whole, or you can crush them into smaller pieces using a blender or food processor.
You may not end up using the entire bag of M&M's.
For a twist, fill the frosting wells with M&M's.
Making Filled Cupcakes Preheat your oven to 350°F (180°C/Gas Mark 4).
Line a standard-sized, 12-hole muffin tin with paper liners.
You can do this method using your own cupcake recipe.
If you are using your own recipe, prepare it as you normally would, then [#cut|click here]] to continue.
Mix together the dry ingredients, except for the sugar.
Pour the flour, cocoa powder, baking soda, and baking powder into a large mixing bowl.
Mix everything together, then set the bowl aside.
Cream the butter and the sugars together.
You can do this in a large bowl with a handheld beater, in a stand mixer, or in a food processor.
Beat the three together until they turn light and fluffy.
Mix in the eggs gradually, then add the milk and vanilla extract.
Add the eggs into the butter mixture one by one.
Beat the mixture well after each egg that you add.
At the very end, stir in the buttermilk and the vanilla extract.
Slowly add the flour mixture into the butter mixture.
Pour half of the flour mixture into the butter mixture.
Stir it in, then add the remaining half.
Mix everything together using a medium speed setting until just combined.
Pour the batter into the prepared muffin tin.
Fill each well no more than ⅔ to ¾ of the way, otherwise the batter may overflow.
To make things easier, use a soup ladle or an ice cream scoop to fill the wells.
Plan on using about 3 tablespoons (45 milliliters) of batter per cupcake.
Bake the cupcakes for 18 to 20 minutes, then let them cool.
The cupcakes are ready when a toothpick inserted into the middle comes out clean.
Let the cupcakes cool in the tin for 5 minutes, then transfer them to a wire rack to finish cooling off.
Cut a well into the middle of each cupcake.
If you have not already, let the cupcakes cool off completely first.
Next, cut a 1-inch (2.54-centimeter) wide, 1-inch (2.54-centimeter) deep hole into each cupcake.
You can do this with a paring knife or with a small spoon.
Discard the pats that you cut out, or save them for making cake pops.
Paring knife: set the knife into the top of the cupcake at a 45-degree angle.
Cut a cone-shape out of the middle of the cupcake.
Spoon: use a melon scoop or a spoon to scoop out the middle of the cupcake.
Fill the wells with mini M&M's.
If you are making these for a gender-reveal party, consider using pink (for a girl) or blue (for a boy).
Set the cupcakes aside when you are done.
Make sure that the inside of the cupcakes are cool before you fill them with M&M's.
If they are warm, the candy will melt.
Prepare the icing.
Cream the butter using a handheld beater, electric mixer, or food processor fitted with whisks.
Beat in 1 cup (125 grams) of the icing sugar,  then add 1 to 2 tablespoons (15 to 30 milliliters) of milk.
Add in the rest of the powdered sugar, 1 cup (125 grams) at a time.
If the frosting is too stiff, add in 1 to 2 more tablespoons (15 to 30 milliliters) of milk.
You can also use your own icing recipe instead.
If this is for a gender reveal party, consider coloring the frosting purple to leave people guessing.
Pipe the frosting onto the cupcakes.
Fit a piping bag with a large, open star tip.
Pipe the frosting onto the cupcakes, making sure to cover up the M&M's.
If you have any M&M's left over, you can stick them on top of the frosting.
You can also grind them up in a blender or food processor, then sprinkle them over the frosting instead.
Finished!
tyn_section: Handheld beater, electric mixer, or food processor
